elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Symmetry codes: a: 1-x, −1.5+y, 0.5-z; b: x, −1+y, z; c: 1- x, −1-y, -z. (b) 2D layer structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis. (c) 3D framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, the hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. (d) Schematic view of the (3, 6)-connected topology of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (the green and purple nodes represent the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands and Zn(II) SBU, respectively).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="at0005" role="short">Fig. 1</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0005" locator="gr1" xlink:href="pii:S002245961830450X/gr1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) Coordination environment of Zn(II) in 1. Symmetry codes: a: 1-x, -1.5+y, 0.5-z; b: x, -1+y, z; c: 1- x, -1-y, -z. (b) 2D layer structure of 1 viewed along the a axis. (c) 3D framework of 1 viewed along the c axis, the hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. (d) Schematic view of the (3, 6)-connected topology of 1 (the green and purple nodes represent the L3- ligands and Zn(II) SBU, respectively).  Fig. 1

<ce:figure id="f0020">

<ce:caption id="cap0020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) Coordination environment of Pb(II) in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Symmetry codes: a: x, y, z; b: x, 1+y, 1+z; c: 2-x, 1-y, 1-z; d: 1+x, 1+y, 1+z. (b) The rod-shape SBUs metal chain along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction. (c) 2D layer structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, the coordinated NMP are omitted for clarity. (d) 3D framework of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis, the hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. (e) Schematic view of the (4,4,6)-connected topology of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (the blue, purple and green nodes represent Pb1(II), Pb2(II) and the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, respectively).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="at0020" role="short">Fig. 4</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0020" locator="gr4" xlink:href="pii:S002245961830450X/gr4" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) Coordination environment of Pb(II) in 4. Symmetry codes: a: x, y, z; b: x, 1+y, 1+z; c: 2-x, 1-y, 1-z; d: 1+x, 1+y, 1+z. (b) The rod-shape SBUs metal chain along the a direction. (c) 2D layer structure of 4 viewed along the b axis, the coordinated NMP are omitted for clarity. (d) 3D framework of 4 viewed along the a axis, the hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. (e) Schematic view of the (4,4,6)-connected topology of 4 (the blue, purple and green nodes represent Pb1(II), Pb2(II) and the L3- ligands, respectively).  Fig. 4

(c) Luminescence spectra of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>@Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> suspensions with Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> concentration varying from 0 to 0.99 mM (excited at 322 nm). </ce:caption>

(c) Luminescence spectra of the 1@Fe3+ suspensions with Fe3+ concentration varying from 0 to 0.99mM (excited at 322nm). (d) The linear correlation for the plot of I0/I vs. the concentration of the Fe3+ ions.  Fig. 8

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0045">
<ce:label>Fig. 9</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0045">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0045" view="all">(a) Luminescence spectra and (b) The luminescence intensity at 370 nm of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in solutions containing various anions, when excited at 322 nm. (c) The luminescence intensity at 370 nm of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in spectra of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>@CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>@H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O suspensions with a CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> concentration varying from 0 to 1.29 mM (excited at 322 nm). (d) The plot of relative luminescence intensity vs. CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> concentration. Insets: The linear correlation for the plot of I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I−1 vs. the concentration of the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ions. (e) Luminescence spectra of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>@Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>@H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O suspensions with Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> concentration varying from 0 to 1.47 mM (excited at 322 nm). (f) The plot of relative luminescence intensity vs. Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> concentration. Insets: The linear correlation for the plot of I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I−1 vs. the concentration of the Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ions.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="at0045" role="short">Fig. 9</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0045" locator="gr9" xlink:href="pii:S002245961830450X/gr9" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 9  (a) Luminescence spectra and (b) The luminescence intensity at 370nm of 1 in solutions containing various anions, when excited at 322nm. (c) The luminescence intensity at 370nm of 1, in spectra of the 1@CrO4 2-@H2O suspensions with a CrO4 2- concentration varying from 0 to 1.29mM (excited at 322nm). (d) The plot of relative luminescence intensity vs. CrO4 2- concentration. Insets: The linear correlation for the plot of I0/I-1 vs. the concentration of the CrO4 2- ions. (e) Luminescence spectra of the 1@Cr2O7 2-@H2O suspensions with Cr2O7 2- concentration varying from 0 to 1.47mM (excited at 322nm). (f) The plot of relative luminescence intensity vs. Cr2O7 2- concentration. Insets: The linear correlation for the plot of I0/I-1 vs. the concentration of the Cr2O7 2- ions.  Fig. 9

<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">Four new water-stable luminescent metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3NMP}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·Diox}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:bold>n</ce:bold>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]·NMP·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and {[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L = 5-(1-(carboxymethyl)pyrazol-3-yl)isophthalic acid; NMP = N-methyl-2-Pyrrolidoneand; Diox = 1,4-Dioxane) have been solvothermally synthesized with different solvents. The single crystal structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveal that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> form the 2D (3,6)-connected <ce:italic>
<ce:bold>kgd</ce:bold>
</ce:italic> nets based on the tetranuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters and trinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters, respectively. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> displays a 2D (3,6)-connected <ce:italic>
<ce:bold>kgd</ce:bold>
</ce:italic> net based on the trinuclear [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] clusters. Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> presents a 2D layer with a rod-shaped SBUs. The solid-state luminescence properties and water stability of these complexes were investigated carefully, showing that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays high selectivity for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> via luminescence quenching effects with low detection limits. The probable quenching mechanisms have been studied in detail.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four new water-stable luminescent metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely {[Zn4(L)2(H2O)4(OH)2]⋅3NMP}n (1), {[Zn3(L)2(H2O)2]⋅Diox} n  (2), {[Cd3(L)2 (H2O)5]⋅NMP⋅3H2O}n (3), and {[Pb3(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O}n (4), (H3L = 5-(1-(carboxymethyl)pyrazol-3-yl)isophthalic acid; NMP=N-methyl-2-Pyrrolidoneand; Diox=1,4-Dioxane) have been solvothermally synthesized with different solvents. The single crystal structures of 1-4 reveal that complexes 1 and 2 form the 2D (3,6)-connected  kgd  nets based on the tetranuclear [Zn4(μ1-COO)2(μ2-COO)4] clusters and trinuclear [Zn3(μ1-COO)2(μ2-COO)4] clusters, respectively. Complex 3 displays a 2D (3,6)-connected  kgd  net based on the trinuclear [Cd3(μ1-COO)4(μ2-COO)2] clusters. Complex 4 presents a 2D layer with a rod-shaped SBUs. The solid-state luminescence properties and water stability of these complexes were investigated carefully, showing that 1 displays high selectivity for Fe3+, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- via luminescence quenching effects with low detection limits. The probable quenching mechanisms have been studied in detail.

Four new Zn/Cd/Pb luminescent metal-organic frameworks have been synthesized and structurally characterized.

The water-stable of complexes 1-4 have been researched.

Compound 1 shows highly selective and sensitive response to Fe3+, CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-.

Introduction

Over the last two decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a series of materials assembled by metal ion with suitable organic ligand have been explored not only for their fantastic structures but also for their great applications in gas storage, separation , catalysis , sensing  and so on. Recently, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) have become a fast growing of crystalline materials for their unique applications in environmental monitoring, medical science, and industrial production . For example, some MOFs exhibit a superb luminescence sensing on cations, anions, gases, and organic molecules . However, the structures of MOFs are vulnerable to the attack of water molecules, which might lead to phase changes, ligand displacement and structure decomposition . Compared with porous carbon materials, zeolites and metal oxides, the limited thermal and chemical stability (especially water stability) of MOFs hampers their popularity in industrial applications, as water or moisture commonly exists in most industrial processes. The secondary building units (SBUs) approach developed by Yaghi and co-workers has been proven to be an effective route for rationally preparing stable MOFs, which is carried out by choosing suitable metal clusters as SBUs with tunable organic ligands as linkers .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Iron is an essential microelement, which plays an indispensable role in physiological functions, including oxygen transport and storage, energy metabolism, cellular proliferation and differentiation, as well as DNA synthesis . Though Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is important for organisms, shortage or excess of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> will result in various serious function condition disorders. Hexavalent (VI) chromium anions (CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>) are sufficiently stable in the environment and high carcinogenic, which are harmful for human health and induce lung cancer, kidney, liver, and blood-forming organs . Therefore, selective sensing and detection of iron over other metal ions is significant for human health. Numerous MOFs have been developed as solid state chemsensors, especially, some MOFs act as bifunctional chemosensors on Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ions . Therefore, highly sensitive sensors for detecting these ions in aqueous solution are very important.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Iron is an essential microelement, which plays an indispensable role in physiological functions, including oxygen transport and storage, energy metabolism, cellular proliferation and differentiation, as well as DNA synthesis . Though Fe3+ is important for organisms, shortage or excess of Fe3+ will result in various serious function condition disorders. Hexavalent (VI) chromium anions (CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-) are sufficiently stable in the environment and high carcinogenic, which are harmful for human health and induce lung cancer, kidney, liver, and blood-forming organs . Therefore, selective sensing and detection of iron over other metal ions is significant for human health. Numerous MOFs have been developed as solid state chemsensors, especially, some MOFs act as bifunctional chemosensors on Fe3+, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- ions . Therefore, highly sensitive sensors for detecting these ions in aqueous solution are very important.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Based on previous works in our group , 5-(1-(carboxymethyl)-pyrazol-3-yl)isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L) (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>
) was chosen to fabricate MOFs considering the following advantages: (i) the marked three carboxylic acid groups and N-atoms in ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L act as multiple coordination sites which would generate various molecular coordination modes; (ii) the multicarboxylic acid groups in H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L would combine with metals to be multinuclear metal-organic clusters, which greatly stabilize the structure and show high stability in aqueous. In this work, four novel MOFs, {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3NMP}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·Diox}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]·NMP·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and {[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) were successfully synthesized under different solvent systems. In particular, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a high sensitivity for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>, and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ions in aqueous solutions by their luminescent quenching effect, which show great potential as a chemosensor on Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>, and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ions in practical. As we expected, the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows excellent luminescence for sensing of metal cations/anions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on previous works in our group , 5-(1-(carboxymethyl)-pyrazol-3-yl)isophthalic acid (H3L) ( ) was chosen to fabricate MOFs considering the following advantages: (i) the marked three carboxylic acid groups and N-atoms in ligand H3L act as multiple coordination sites which would generate various molecular coordination modes; (ii) the multicarboxylic acid groups in H3L would combine with metals to be multinuclear metal-organic clusters, which greatly stabilize the structure and show high stability in aqueous. In this work, four novel MOFs, {[Zn4(L)2(H2O)4(OH)2]⋅3NMP}n (1), {[Zn3(L)2(H2O)2]⋅Diox}n (2), {[Cd3(L)2(H2O)5]⋅NMP⋅3H2O}n (3), and {[Pb3(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O}n (4) were successfully synthesized under different solvent systems. In particular, 1 exhibits a high sensitivity for Fe3+, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- ions in aqueous solutions by their luminescent quenching effect, which show great potential as a chemosensor on Fe3+, CrO4 2-, and Cr2O7 2- ions in practical. As we expected, the complex 1 shows excellent luminescence for sensing of metal cations/anions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Materials and physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">All the solvents and reagents employed in this work were commercially sources and used directly without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N atoms were measured on a PerkinElmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were taken on a Nicolet Avatar 360 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer in the range 4000–400 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> by using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted with a heating rate of 10 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> stream employing the NETZSCH STA 449 C microanalyzer thermal analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu K, 1.5418 Å). The luminescence spectra of the solid state samples were tested on a Hitachi F-4500 at room temperature. UV–vis spectroscopic studies were measured on a Hitachi U-3310 spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded under a ultra-high vacuum (< 10<ce:sup loc="post">−7</ce:sup> Pa) at a pass energy of 55 eV on a PerkinElmer PHI 5000C ESCA system using a Al Kα (1486 eV) anode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and physical measurements

All the solvents and reagents employed in this work were commercially sources and used directly without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N atoms were measured on a PerkinElmer 2400C elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were taken on a Nicolet Avatar 360 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer in the range 4000-400cm-1 by using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 under a N2 stream employing the NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer thermal analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu K, 1.5418Å). The luminescence spectra of the solid state samples were tested on a Hitachi F-4500 at room temperature. UV-vis spectroscopic studies were measured on a Hitachi U-3310 spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded under a ultra-high vacuum (<10-7 Pa) at a pass energy of 55eV on a PerkinElmer PHI 5000C ESCA system using a Al Kα (1486eV) anode.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray data collection and structure determinations

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses for 1-4 were collected via a Bruker SMART APEXII CCD diffractometer with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation source (λ=0.71073Å) at 296(2) K. All structures are analyzed and refined using a direct and full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms (SHELXL-97), respectively . The solvent molecules in 4 were highly disordered and removed from the diffraction data using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON . Crystal data and structure refinements for 1-4 and selected bond distances and angles are given in   and , respectively. CCDC numbers are 1858665-1858668 for 1-4, respectively.

<ce:section-title id="sect0065">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0070">Crystal structure of {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3NMP}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">X-ray crystallography reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>21<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, two coordinated water molecules and one OH<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> anion. As shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
a, Zn1 is six connected by two O atoms from two L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, two water molecules, and two OH<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> anions, forming a distorted octahedral geometry. Different from that of Zn1, Zn2 is four connected by three carboxylate O atoms from three L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, and O atom from an OH<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> anion, showing a distorted tetrahedron coordination geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.952(4) to 2.154(4) Å, and the O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 81.18° to 173.32°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of {[Zn4(L)2(H2O)4(OH)2]⋅3NMP}n (1)

X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L3-, two coordinated water molecules and one OH- anion. As shown in  a, Zn1 is six connected by two O atoms from two L3- ligands, two water molecules, and two OH- anions, forming a distorted octahedral geometry. Different from that of Zn1, Zn2 is four connected by three carboxylate O atoms from three L3-, and O atom from an OH- anion, showing a distorted tetrahedron coordination geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.952(4) to 2.154(4)Å, and the O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 81.18° to 173.32°.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> shows one coordination mode (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>
a), and three carboxylate groups exhibit two different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), and monodentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>), to coordinate with five Zn(II) ions. Otherwise, four Zn(II) ions are connected by three bridging carboxylate groups and one monodentate carboxylate group to form a tetranuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters as SBU with the Zn1⋯Zn1 and Zn1⋯Zn2 separations of 3.1742(16) and 3.3737(11) Å, respectively (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The SBU is extended by six L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands to produce a 2D layered network viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (b), and this further form a 3D supramolecular structure via C-H⋯O weak interactions (c,  and .). Topologically, the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligand and SBU can be considered as 3- and 6-connected nodes, respectively. Thus, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> discloses a (3,6)-connected <ce:italic>
<ce:bold>kgd</ce:bold>
</ce:italic> topology with a point symbol of {4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> 6<ce:sup loc="post">6.</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>} (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 1, L3- shows one coordination mode (    a), and three carboxylate groups exhibit two different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2), and monodentate (η1μ1χ1), to coordinate with five Zn(II) ions. Otherwise, four Zn(II) ions are connected by three bridging carboxylate groups and one monodentate carboxylate group to form a tetranuclear [Zn4(μ1-COO)2(μ2-COO)4] clusters as SBU with the Zn1⋯Zn1 and Zn1⋯Zn2 separations of 3.1742(16) and 3.3737(11) Å, respectively ( a). The SBU is extended by six L3- ligands to produce a 2D layered network viewed along the a axis (b), and this further form a 3D supramolecular structure via C-H⋯O weak interactions (c,  and .). Topologically, the L3- ligand and SBU can be considered as 3- and 6-connected nodes, respectively. Thus, 1 discloses a (3,6)-connected  kgd  topology with a point symbol of {43}2{46 66.83} (d).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0075">Crystal structure of {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·Diox}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (2)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">X-ray crystallography reveals that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī and contains one and a half crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom, which is connected by six O atoms from four L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands and two water molecules, shows a distorted octahedral geometry; while Zn2 atom, which is five connected by four carboxylate O atoms from three L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> and one N atom, shows a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.940 (2) to 2.569 (3) Å and the Zn-N distances vary from 2.088 (3) Å. The O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 55.77 (10)° to 180.00 (11)° and the O-Zn-N angles are in the range from 91.22 (9)° to 109.22 (10)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Zn3(L)3(H2O)2]⋅Diox}n (2)

X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group Pī and contains one and a half crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L3-, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom, which is connected by six O atoms from four L3- ligands and two water molecules, shows a distorted octahedral geometry; while Zn2 atom, which is five connected by four carboxylate O atoms from three L3- and one N atom, shows a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.940 (2) to 2.569 (3)Å and the Zn-N distances vary from 2.088 (3)Å. The O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 55.77 (10)° to 180.00 (11)° and the O-Zn-N angles are in the range from 91.22 (9)° to 109.22 (10)°.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> shows one coordination mode (b), and three carboxylate groups reveal three different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), bridging chelating (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), and monodentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) to coordinate with five Zn(II) ions. In addition, three Zn(II) ions are connected by four bridging carboxylate groups and two monodentate carboxylate groups to form a trinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] SBU (b), the SBU is by the Zn1⋯Zn2 separations of 3.2876(4) Å. The SBU is extended by six L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands to produce a 2D layered network viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction (b). Finally, the O-H⋯O connected by solvent molecules exist between the neighboring 2D layers, which combine the layers into a 3D supramolecular network (c,  and ). Finally, the O-H⋯O connected by solvent molecules exist between the neighboring 2D layers, which combine the layers into a 3D supramolecular network (c,  and ). Topologically, the L3- ligand and SBU can be considered as 3, 6-connected nodes, respectively. Thus, 2 discloses a (3,6)-connected  kgd  topology with a point symbol of {43}2{46 66.83} (d).

Crystal structure of {[Cd3(L)2 (H2O)5]⋅NMP⋅3H2O}n (3)

X-ray crystallography shows that complex 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group Pī. The asymmetric unit is made up of three crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions, two fully deprotonated L3- (La and Lb), adopting different coordination models with Cd(II) ions (c), and five coordinated water molecules. As shown in a, Cd1 atom, which is six connected by one N atom from Lb ligand, one water molecule and four O atoms from three Lb ligands, displays a distorted octahedron geometry. Cd2 and Cd3 show a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. Cd2 is seven connected by four O atoms from one La and one Lb ligand, respectively, and three O atoms from three H2O molecules; Cd3 is seven connected by one N atom and five O atoms from three La ligands and one H2O molecule. The Cd-O distances vary from 2.193 (4) to 2.756 (5)Å and the Cd-N distances vary from 2.342 (5) to 2.373 (5)Å. The O-Cd-O angles are in the range from 51.51° to 176.2° and the O-Cd-N angles are in the range from 81.74° to 171.0°.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0085">Crystal structure of {[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (4)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">X-ray crystallography reveals that complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Pb(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, one coordinated NMP molecule, and one half coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule. Structural analysis reveals that there exists 1D infinite rod-shaped metal chain SBUs in the crystal structure (b). As shown in a, there are two types of Pb(II) atoms in the rod SBU. Pb1 is six connected by six O atoms from four L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, Pb2 is six connected by three O atoms from three L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, one H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule and two NMP molecules. The Pb-O distances vary from 1.026 (13) to 2.748 (5) Å, and the O-Pb-O angles are in the range from 50.12° to 160.12°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Pb3(L)2⋅(NMP)2⋅(H2O)]⋅H2O}n (4)

X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group Pī. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Pb(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L3-, one coordinated NMP molecule, and one half coordinated H2O molecule. Structural analysis reveals that there exists 1D infinite rod-shaped metal chain SBUs in the crystal structure (b). As shown in a, there are two types of Pb(II) atoms in the rod SBU. Pb1 is six connected by six O atoms from four L3- ligands, Pb2 is six connected by three O atoms from three L3- ligands, one H2O molecule and two NMP molecules. The Pb-O distances vary from 1.026 (13) to 2.748 (5) Å, and the O-Pb-O angles are in the range from 50.12° to 160.12°.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0100" view="all">In <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> shows one coordination mode (d), and three carboxylate groups display two different coordination modes: bridging tridentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) and bridging tridentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>), to coordinate with seven Pb(II) ions. The rod-shape SBU metal chains link together to form a 2D layer via L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands linkers viewed along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> direction, which further hold together to construct a 3D supramolecular structure by C-H⋯O weak interactions (c,  and ). Topology analysis indicates that the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligand as a 6-connected node, Pb1 and Pb2 are as 4-connected node, so, the 2D layer can be rationalized as (4,4,6)-connected network (e).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 4, L3- shows one coordination mode (d), and three carboxylate groups display two different coordination modes: bridging tridentate (η2μ2χ3) and bridging tridentate (η2μ3χ3), to coordinate with seven Pb(II) ions. The rod-shape SBU metal chains link together to form a 2D layer via L3- ligands linkers viewed along the b direction, which further hold together to construct a 3D supramolecular structure by C-H⋯O weak interactions (c,  and ). Topology analysis indicates that the L3- ligand as a 6-connected node, Pb1 and Pb2 are as 4-connected node, so, the 2D layer can be rationalized as (4,4,6)-connected network (e).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0090">The influence of the coordination modes of the ligand and clusters on the assembly of the structure</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Structural analyses show that the solvent system and molecular configuration of ligand play the vital roles for the final structures of MOFs. In hydrothermal conditions, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L assumes fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Among these, the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> displays five different coordination modes (a-d), the carboxylate group adopts six different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), and monodentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; bridging bidentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), bridging chelating (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), and monodentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; monodentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>), bridging chelating (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), and bridging tridentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; bridging tridentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>), and bridging tridentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The influence of the coordination modes of the ligand and clusters on the assembly of the structure

Structural analyses show that the solvent system and molecular configuration of ligand play the vital roles for the final structures of MOFs. In hydrothermal conditions, H3L assumes fully deprotonated L3- in 1-4. Among these, the L3- ligand in 1-4 displays five different coordination modes (a-d), the carboxylate group adopts six different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2), and monodentate (η1μ1χ1) in 1; bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2), bridging chelating (η2μ1χ2), and monodentate (η1μ2χ2) in 2; monodentate (η1μ1χ1), bridging chelating (η2μ1χ2), and bridging tridentate (η2μ2χ3) in 3; bridging tridentate (η2μ2χ3), and bridging tridentate (η2μ3χ3) in 4.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0110" view="all">The different coordination modes of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> may be attributed to the radius of Pb(II) are larger than these of Zn(II) and Cd(II), thus Pb(II) can connect more active atoms . Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> form a 2D layer structure based on tetranuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters and trinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters, respectively, which suggest that although H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L coordinate with the same number of metal ions, however, the different coordination modes of carboxylates play an important role in determining the distinction of metal cluster (a, b). Moreover, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> formed 2D structure by connecting the ligand and SBU (). 4 forms a 2D structure by links 1D infinite rod-shaped metal chain SBU and the ligand (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The different coordination modes of 1, 3 and 4 may be attributed to the radius of Pb(II) are larger than these of Zn(II) and Cd(II), thus Pb(II) can connect more active atoms . Complexes 1 and 2 form a 2D layer structure based on tetranuclear [Zn4(μ1-COO)2 (μ2-COO)4] clusters and trinuclear [Zn3(μ1-COO)2(μ2-COO)4] clusters, respectively, which suggest that although H3L coordinate with the same number of metal ions, however, the different coordination modes of carboxylates play an important role in determining the distinction of metal cluster (a, b). Moreover, 1-3 formed 2D structure by connecting the ligand and SBU (). 4 forms a 2D structure by links 1D infinite rod-shaped metal chain SBU and the ligand (b).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0095">PXRD and thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The PXRD data reveals that the peak positions of the synthesized crystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> matched with the simulated results from the single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the synthesized samples (). The TGA of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carried out under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere from 35 to 700 °C (). 1 releases three coordinated NMP molecule before 265 °C with a total weight loss of 22.8% (calcd. 23.9%). No further weight loss is observed before the framework collapses at 380 °C. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> loses 9.7% (calcd. 9.8%) weight before 168 °C, corresponding to the departure of one Diox molecule, and the framework could keep intact until about 415 °C, showing good thermal stability. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> loses 11.3% (calcd. 13.3%) weight before 140 °C is assigned to the loss of one free NMP and three coordinated water molecules. The main framework is thermally stable up to 330 °C and then decomposes at a higher temperature. <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> presents a weight loss of 2.1% (calcd. 2.5%) before 190 °C, arising from the release of one coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and one lattice H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and thermal analyses

The PXRD data reveals that the peak positions of the synthesized crystalline samples of 1-4 matched with the simulated results from the single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the synthesized samples (). The TGA of 1-4 were carried out under a N2 atmosphere from 35 to 700°C (). 1 releases three coordinated NMP molecule before 265°C with a total weight loss of 22.8% (calcd. 23.9%). No further weight loss is observed before the framework collapses at 380°C. 2 loses 9.7% (calcd. 9.8%) weight before 168°C, corresponding to the departure of one Diox molecule, and the framework could keep intact until about 415°C, showing good thermal stability. 3 loses 11.3% (calcd. 13.3%) weight before 140°C is assigned to the loss of one free NMP and three coordinated water molecules. The main framework is thermally stable up to 330°C and then decomposes at a higher temperature. 4 presents a weight loss of 2.1% (calcd. 2.5%) before 190°C, arising from the release of one coordinated H2O and one lattice H2O molecules.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0100">Water stability of 1–4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In order to further study the water stability of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the experiments were carried out by immersing 40 mg of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystals in 5 mL in water at room temperature for some time and the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystalline structures were confirmed by PXRD, respectively. The PXRD patterns contained for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>@H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O are the coincidence of the experimental PXRD patterns with those simulated from the single-crystal structures, respectively, revealing excellent stability in water ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Water stability of 1-4

In order to further study the water stability of the 1-4, the experiments were carried out by immersing 40mg of 1-4 crystals in 5mL in water at room temperature for some time and the 1-4 crystalline structures were confirmed by PXRD, respectively. The PXRD patterns contained for 1-4@H2O are the coincidence of the experimental PXRD patterns with those simulated from the single-crystal structures, respectively, revealing excellent stability in water ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0105">Luminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Complexes constructed by d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal centers and conjugated organic linkers are promising candidates in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this paper, the solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligands and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were studied at room temperature. As displayed in , the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L show a strong emission peak at 375 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 330 nm), which may be derived from the intraligand π*-π and/or π*-n transition. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibit a maximum emission peak at 369 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 319 nm), 385 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 330 nm), 453 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 343 nm) and 515 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 356 nm), respectively. The emission spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a slight blue shift of 6 nm at 375 nm compared to that of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L ligand, which can be assigned to the intraligand π-π* or n-π* transition of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L. The emission spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays the slight red shift of 10 nm for the 375 nm band compared to that of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L ligand, which may arise from the ligandcentered π-π* electronic transitions compared to the reported luminescent d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> MOFs . Complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibit an obvious red-shifts of 78 nm and 140 nm for the 375 nm band, respectively, which can be attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of carboxylate groups and p orbitals of Cd(II) and Pb(II) centers, respectively . Moreover, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has an enhanced luminescence intensity compared to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, which can be explained by the differences in the structures. The different emission intensity for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> mainly derives from the differences in the coordination modes of the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligand, and the coordination environments of the metal ions and the rigidity of the solid-state crystal packing. Whereas the rigid and stable framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can reduce this loss of energy and thus maintaining enhanced luminescence intensity. More importantly, it is sensing properties were further researched to detect different metal ions in aqueous solution <ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

Complexes constructed by d10 metal centers and conjugated organic linkers are promising candidates in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this paper, the solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligands and 1-4 were studied at room temperature. As displayed in , the free H3L show a strong emission peak at 375nm (λex =330nm), which may be derived from the intraligand π*-π and/or π*-n transition. Complexes 1-4 exhibit a maximum emission peak at 369nm (λex =319nm), 385nm (λex =330nm), 453nm (λex =343nm) and 515nm (λex =356nm), respectively. The emission spectrum of 1 exhibits a slight blue shift of 6nm at 375nm compared to that of H3L ligand, which can be assigned to the intraligand π-π* or n-π* transition of H3L. The emission spectrum of 2 displays the slight red shift of 10nm for the 375nm band compared to that of H3L ligand, which may arise from the ligandcentered π-π* electronic transitions compared to the reported luminescent d10 MOFs . Complexes 3-4 exhibit an obvious red-shifts of 78nm and 140nm for the 375nm band, respectively, which can be attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of carboxylate groups and p orbitals of Cd(II) and Pb(II) centers, respectively . Moreover, complex 1 has an enhanced luminescence intensity compared to 2-4, which can be explained by the differences in the structures. The different emission intensity for 1-4 mainly derives from the differences in the coordination modes of the L3- ligand, and the coordination environments of the metal ions and the rigidity of the solid-state crystal packing. Whereas the rigid and stable framework of 1 can reduce this loss of energy and thus maintaining enhanced luminescence intensity. More importantly, it is sensing properties were further researched to detect different metal ions in aqueous solution  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0110">Detection of cations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The intense emission and good water stability of the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> impelled us to study their luminescence sensing characteristics. In order to examine the potential of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for sensing cations, 3 mg of crystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were dispersed into 3 mL of water solutions of M(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (M = Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Mg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ag<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, respectively) (1 mM) for half an hour of ultrasonic oscillation, forming a series of suspension prior to fluorescence measurements for the detection studies. As shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>
(a, b), Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Mg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> possessing a closed-shell electron configuration, they have a trivial effect on the luminescence intensity. However, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, which could produce varying degrees of quenching of the luminescence intensity. This difference may be due to that the outer layers of Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions comprise the semi-saturated or unsaturated electronic state, which makes the ions ideal acceptors . For Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> causing the most significant changes imply that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be considered as a potential candidate for selective probing of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>
. The result indicates that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has highly selective detection and specific recognition of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in water solutions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Detection of cations

The intense emission and good water stability of the complex 1 impelled us to study their luminescence sensing characteristics. In order to examine the potential of 1 for sensing cations, 3mg of crystalline samples of 1 were dispersed into 3mL of water solutions of M(NO3)n (M=Pb2+, Zn2+, Mg2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Cd2+, Ag+, Fe3+, respectively) (1mM) for half an hour of ultrasonic oscillation, forming a series of suspension prior to fluorescence measurements for the detection studies. As shown in  (a, b), Zn2+ and Mg2+ possessing a closed-shell electron configuration, they have a trivial effect on the luminescence intensity. However, Cu2+, Cd2+, Ni2+ and Fe3+, which could produce varying degrees of quenching of the luminescence intensity. This difference may be due to that the outer layers of Cu2+, Ni2+ and Fe3+ ions comprise the semi-saturated or unsaturated electronic state, which makes the ions ideal acceptors . For Fe3+ causing the most significant changes imply that compound 1 can be considered as a potential candidate for selective probing of Fe3+ . The result indicates that 1 has highly selective detection and specific recognition of Fe3+ ions in water solutions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0135" view="all">To assess the sensitivity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> toward Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in detail, varying concentrations of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> were introduced into suspension of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The results from a titration experiment (c) shown that the luminescence intensity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> clearly decrease gradually with increasing. The Stern-Volmer equation was used to calculate the corresponding quenching coefficients, showing it to be a diffusion-controlled quenching process . The relationship between the relative luminescence intensity and the concentration of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions can be fitted well with the Stern-Volmer formula: I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I = 6 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> [M] <ce:bold>+</ce:bold> 0.86 (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.995), showing that luminescence quenching is diffusion-controlled (I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> = the luminescence intensity of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>@H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O suspension; I = the luminescence intensity of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>@Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> suspensions, [M] = the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> concentration (mM)) (d). When the concentration of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions reached 0.99 mM, the luminescence intensity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is quenched with quenching efficiency of 86% (quenching percentage = (I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>−I)/I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> × 100%). For Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, the SV plots are nearly linear in the low concentration range and the K<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf> value is calculated to about 6 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> (d), the calculated detection limit of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions can reach as low as 1.25 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">-5</ce:sup> M according to 3δ/K<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf>, where δ is standard error and K is slope. The high K<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> value and low detection limit, which is compared to previously reported compounds for sensing Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> []. The lower detection limit suggests that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits high detection sensitivity toward Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To assess the sensitivity of 1 toward Fe3+ in detail, varying concentrations of Fe3+ were introduced into suspension of 1. The results from a titration experiment (c) shown that the luminescence intensity of 1 clearly decrease gradually with increasing. The Stern-Volmer equation was used to calculate the corresponding quenching coefficients, showing it to be a diffusion-controlled quenching process . The relationship between the relative luminescence intensity and the concentration of Fe3+ ions can be fitted well with the Stern-Volmer formula: I0/I=6×103 [M]+0.86 (R2 =0.995), showing that luminescence quenching is diffusion-controlled (I0 =the luminescence intensity of the 1@H2O suspension; I = the luminescence intensity of the 1@Fe3+ suspensions, [M] = the Fe3+ concentration (mM)) (d). When the concentration of Fe3+ ions reached 0.99mM, the luminescence intensity of 1 is quenched with quenching efficiency of 86% (quenching percentage = (I0-I)/I0 ×100%). For Fe3+, the SV plots are nearly linear in the low concentration range and the Ksv value is calculated to about 6×103 M-1 (d), the calculated detection limit of complex 1 for Fe3+ ions can reach as low as 1.25×10-5 M according to 3δ/Ksv, where δ is standard error and K is slope. The high KSV value and low detection limit, which is compared to previously reported compounds for sensing Fe3+ []. The lower detection limit suggests that complex 1 exhibits high detection sensitivity toward Fe3+.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0140" view="all">Furthermore, the multiple cycles of the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> sensing experiments were performed and the obtained results illustrated that the material can regain its luminescence intensity after washing with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (). The result reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be employed as a fluorescent sensor for detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> with high sensitivity and recyclability.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the multiple cycles of the Fe3+ sensing experiments were performed and the obtained results illustrated that the material can regain its luminescence intensity after washing with H2O (). The result reveals that 1 can be employed as a fluorescent sensor for detecting Fe3+ with high sensitivity and recyclability.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0145" view="all">The reason why Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions cause the luminescence quenching was basically attributed to collapse of the framework, cationic exchange, competition absorption between the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions and MOFs, and/or strong framework Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> interactions . The PXRD patterns of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured by various metal ion solutions, which were stable after sensing Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions (), indicating that luminescent quenching of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions resulting from collapse of the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be ruled out. The UV–vis absorption spectrum of the Fe(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in water solutions shows no overlap with the excitation spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in water solutions (). Therefore, it can be explained that it is not competitive adsorption between Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The outer layers of the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are in an unsaturated electronic state (d<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>), meaning that the ions have empty orbitals and are ideal acceptors for electrons . Moreover, the O 1s X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were discussed on <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>@<ce:bold>Fe</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:bold>3+</ce:bold>
</ce:sup> (). The O 1s peaks from free oxygen atoms of monodentate carboxylate at 530.21 eV get shifted to 533.21 eV on the addition of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> (). Such a shift reflects the decrease in the electron density of the O, indicating that the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cations were coordinated with the oxygen atoms in the MOFs framework .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The reason why Fe3+ ions cause the luminescence quenching was basically attributed to collapse of the framework, cationic exchange, competition absorption between the Fe3+ ions and MOFs, and/or strong framework Fe3+ interactions . The PXRD patterns of 1 were measured by various metal ion solutions, which were stable after sensing Fe3+ ions (), indicating that luminescent quenching of Fe3+ ions resulting from collapse of the framework of 1 can be ruled out. The UV-vis absorption spectrum of the Fe(NO3)3 in water solutions shows no overlap with the excitation spectrum of 1 in water solutions (). Therefore, it can be explained that it is not competitive adsorption between Fe3+ ions and 1. The outer layers of the Fe3+ ions are in an unsaturated electronic state (d6), meaning that the ions have empty orbitals and are ideal acceptors for electrons . Moreover, the O 1s X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were discussed on 1 and 1@Fe  3+  (). The O 1s peaks from free oxygen atoms of monodentate carboxylate at 530.21eV get shifted to 533.21eV on the addition of Fe3+ (). Such a shift reflects the decrease in the electron density of the O, indicating that the Fe3+ cations were coordinated with the oxygen atoms in the MOFs framework .

elements.clean_text:
Detection of anions

Simultaneously, various anions were selected to carry out the anion-sensing function by immersing 1 in different anion aqueous solutions (anion = Br-, I-, SO4 2-, C2O4 2-, CO3 2-, Cl-, Cr2O7 2-, CrO4 2-, respectively). The luminescent measurements illustrate that the difference of anions has a great influence in the luminescence intensity of 1. For example, the luminescence intensity at 369nm is slightly enhanced by the addition of Br-, I-, SO4 2-, C2O4 2- and CO3 2- ions, respectively. While the Cl- anion caused a slight decrease in the luminescence intensity of 1. Surprisingly, the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions exhibited an obvious quenching effect. These results suggest the high selectivity of 1 for the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions compared to the other anions ( a, b).

For the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anions, the plot of I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I vs. [M] can be well fitted by the Stern-Volmer equation I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I = 1 + K<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf>[M] and the SV plots are nearly linear in the low concentration range (d, f, insets). The K<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf> values were calculated to about 1.2 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup> and 5.78 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>, respectively. According to the K<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf> values and the standard deviations for repeated luminescence measurements of blank solutions, the detection limits (3δ/k<ce:inf loc="post">sv</ce:inf>) of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was also calculated. The low detection limits indicate that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits extremely high detection sensitivity toward the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text: To further prove that the fluorescence quenching by the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-, concentration-dependent studies in the luminescence properties of 1. As shown in (c, f), the luminescence intensity of the 1 suspension declines sharply with the increase of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- concentration from 0 to 1×10-3 M. When the concentration of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- were increased to 1.29 and 1.47mM, the luminescence was completely quenched with a high quenching efficiency of 93% and 98%, respectively. The relationship between I0/I and the concentration of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions didn't fit the Stern-Volmer equation, indicating the coexistence of a dynamic and static quenching process, which can be well fitted as the following formula: I0/I =4.492exp([M]/ 0.683) - 4.007 and I0/I=0.714exp([M]/0.347)+0.195, respectively (I0 and I are the luminescence intensity of the 1@H2O and 1@anion suspensions, respectively; [M] is the concentration (mM) of the anion). For the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions, the plot of I0/I vs. [M] can be well fitted by the Stern-Volmer equation I0/I=1+Ksv[M] and the SV plots are nearly linear in the low concentration range (d, f, insets). The Ksv values were calculated to about 1.2×104 M-1 and 5.78×103 M-1, respectively. According to the Ksv values and the standard deviations for repeated luminescence measurements of blank solutions, the detection limits (3δ/ksv) of complex 1 was also calculated. For complex 1, the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions are the most obviously quenchers with detection limits of 2.2×10-6 M, 1.7×10-5 M, which are compared to the reported values of some other compounds in the literature []. The low detection limits indicate that complex 1 exhibits extremely high detection sensitivity toward the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-.

Therefore, 1 could be used as a luminescence sensor to detect CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions with high sensitivity and recyclability.

<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anions has also been further researched. Firstly, after being immersed in anion solutions, the PXRD patterns of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showed that their structures were still intact (). Secondly, the change in luminescence intensity may be explained by the electron-transfer transitions of the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anions, reducing the energy transfer between the π and π* orbitals of the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands . From the UV–vis absorption spectra that only overlaps of the absorption range between the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anions and the excitation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were observed, proving that the competitive adsorption of excitation wavelength energy between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> anions are responsible for the luminescence quenching (). In other words, two types of quenching pathway coexist in a competitive manner with another, which factor playing the key role mainly depends on the CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> concentration.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, a possible sensing mechanism for the luminescence quenching by the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions has also been further researched. Firstly, after being immersed in anion solutions, the PXRD patterns of 1 showed that their structures were still intact (). Secondly, the change in luminescence intensity may be explained by the electron-transfer transitions of the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions, reducing the energy transfer between the π and π* orbitals of the L3- ligands . From the UV-vis absorption spectra that only overlaps of the absorption range between the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions and the excitation of 1 were observed, proving that the competitive adsorption of excitation wavelength energy between 1 and CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions are responsible for the luminescence quenching (). In other words, two types of quenching pathway coexist in a competitive manner with another, which factor playing the key role mainly depends on the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- concentration.

<ce:section-title id="sect0120">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0170" view="all">In summary, four new complexes were successfully constructed by employing tricarboxylic acid as an organic ligand, which possess versatile coordination sites and manifold coordination modes to produce various SBUs to obtain MOFs with good water stability. The single crystal structures of <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold> were 2D nets. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a remarkable quenching effect in the luminescence emission of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> upon the introduction of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, CrO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> and Cr<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>. Clearly, the water-stable MOFs with functional groups hold great potential as a promising luminescence sensing material for metal ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, four new complexes were successfully constructed by employing tricarboxylic acid as an organic ligand, which possess versatile coordination sites and manifold coordination modes to produce various SBUs to obtain MOFs with good water stability. The single crystal structures of 1-4 were 2D nets. Complex 1 shows a remarkable quenching effect in the luminescence emission of 1 upon the introduction of Fe3+, CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-. Clearly, the water-stable MOFs with functional groups hold great potential as a promising luminescence sensing material for metal ions.

Synthesis of {[Zn4(L)2(H2O)4(OH)2]⋅3NMP}n (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol), and H3L (14.5mg, 0.05mmol) in NMP (4mL) and distilled water (2mL) were sealed a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25mL) and heated at 150°C for 72h, and gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1. Colorless crystals of 1 were gained by filtration and washed with NMP. Yield: 27.6mg, 44.52% (based on H3L ligand). Anal. calcd (%) for C41H51N7O21Zn4: C, 39.69; H, 4.11; N, 7.91. Found: C, 39.45; H, 4.13; N, 7.85. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3380(m), 3106(w), 3000(w), 2925(w), 1517(s), 1448(s), 1377(s), 1245(m), 1103(m), 1063(s), 879(m), 773(s), 734(s), 584(m).

Synthesis of {[Zn3(L)2(H2O)2]⋅Diox}n (2)

The synthesis procedure used was similar to that of 1, except that NMP was used replaced by Diox in the synthetic procedure. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 30.0mg, 66.67% (based on H3L ligand). Anal. calcd (%) for C30H26N4O16Zn3: C, 40.23; H, 2.91; N, 1.56. Found: C, 40.42; H, 2.88; N, 1.62. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3407(m), 3114(w), 1868(w), 1509(s), 1442(s), 1369(s), 1311(w), 1112(s), 1072(m), 777(m), 597(s).

Synthesis of {[Cd3(L)2(H2O)5]⋅NMP⋅3H2O}n (3)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (30.8mg, 0.1mmol), and H3L (14.5mg, 0.05mmol) in NMP (2mL) and distilled water (2mL) were placed into a glass vial (10mL) and heated at 105°C for 72h, and gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1. Colorless crystals of 3 were collected by filtration and washed with NMP. Yield: 30.2mg, 52.06% (based on H3L ligand). Anal. calcd (%) for C31H39N5O21Cd3: C, 32.21; H, 3.38; N, 6.06. Found: C, 32.13; H, 3.34; N, 6.24. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3594(w), 3345(w), 3114(m), 2937(w), 2875(w), 1841(w), 1511(s), 1446(m), 1396(w), 1365(s), 1303(m), 1243(w), 1176(w), 1112(w), 1066(s), 784(s), 728(s), 663(w), 572(w).

Synthesis of {[Pb3(L)2(NMP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O}n (4)

A mixture of Pb(NO3)2 (33.1mg, 0.1mmol), and H3L (14.5mg, 0.05mmol) in NMP (4mL) and distilled water (2mL) were sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25mL) and heated at 130°C for 72h, and gradually cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1. Colorless crystals of 4 were collected by filtration and washed with H 2 O. Yield: 30.1mg, 42.15% (based on H 3 L ligand). Anal. calcd (%) for C36H36N6O16Pb3: C, 30.20; H, 2.52; N, 5.87. Found: C, 30.32; H, 2.63; N, 5.74. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3390(m), 3118(m), 2979(w), 2940(w), 2875(w), 1874 (w), 1508(m), 1448(w), 1398(w), 1340(m), 1295(s), 1348(s), 1236(w), 1105(m), 1058(m), 773(s), 727(s), 692(m), 622(w).
