<ce:section-title id="sect0065">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0070">Crystal structure of {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3NMP}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">X-ray crystallography reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>21<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, two coordinated water molecules and one OH<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> anion. As shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
a, Zn1 is six connected by two O atoms from two L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, two water molecules, and two OH<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> anions, forming a distorted octahedral geometry. Different from that of Zn1, Zn2 is four connected by three carboxylate O atoms from three L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, and O atom from an OH<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> anion, showing a distorted tetrahedron coordination geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.952(4) to 2.154(4) Å, and the O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 81.18° to 173.32°.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0075">Crystal structure of {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·Diox}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (2)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">X-ray crystallography reveals that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī and contains one and a half crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom, which is connected by six O atoms from four L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands and two water molecules, shows a distorted octahedral geometry; while Zn2 atom, which is five connected by four carboxylate O atoms from three L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> and one N atom, shows a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.940 (2) to 2.569 (3) Å and the Zn-N distances vary from 2.088 (3) Å. The O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 55.77 (10)° to 180.00 (11)° and the O-Zn-N angles are in the range from 91.22 (9)° to 109.22 (10)°.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> shows one coordination mode (b), and three carboxylate groups reveal three different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), bridging chelating (η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), and monodentate (η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>χ<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) to coordinate with five Zn(II) ions. In addition, three Zn(II) ions are connected by four bridging carboxylate groups and two monodentate carboxylate groups to form a trinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] SBU (b), the SBU is by the Zn1⋯Zn2 separations of 3.2876(4) Å. The SBU is extended by six L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands to produce a 2D layered network viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction (b). Finally, the O-H⋯O connected by solvent molecules exist between the neighboring 2D layers, which combine the layers into a 3D supramolecular network (c,  and ). Topologically, the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligand and SBU can be considered as 3, 6-connected nodes, respectively. Thus, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> discloses a (3,6)-connected <ce:italic>
<ce:bold>kgd</ce:bold>
</ce:italic> topology with a point symbol of {4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> 6<ce:sup loc="post">6.</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>} (d).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0080">Crystal structure of {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]·NMP·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (3)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">X-ray crystallography shows that complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī. The asymmetric unit is made up of three crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions, two fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> (La and Lb), adopting different coordination models with Cd(II) ions (c), and five coordinated water molecules. As shown in a, Cd1 atom, which is six connected by one N atom from Lb ligand, one water molecule and four O atoms from three Lb ligands, displays a distorted octahedron geometry. Cd2 and Cd3 show a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. Cd2 is seven connected by four O atoms from one La and one Lb ligand, respectively, and three O atoms from three H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules; Cd3 is seven connected by one N atom and five O atoms from three La ligands and one H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule. The Cd-O distances vary from 2.193 (4) to 2.756 (5) Å and the Cd-N distances vary from 2.342 (5) to 2.373 (5) Å. The O-Cd-O angles are in the range from 51.51° to 176.2° and the O-Cd-N angles are in the range from 81.74° to 171.0°.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0085">Crystal structure of {[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·(NMP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (4)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">X-ray crystallography reveals that complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Pb(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup>, one coordinated NMP molecule, and one half coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule. Structural analysis reveals that there exists 1D infinite rod-shaped metal chain SBUs in the crystal structure (b). As shown in a, there are two types of Pb(II) atoms in the rod SBU. Pb1 is six connected by six O atoms from four L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, Pb2 is six connected by three O atoms from three L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligands, one H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule and two NMP molecules. The Pb-O distances vary from 1.026 (13) to 2.748 (5) Å, and the O-Pb-O angles are in the range from 50.12° to 160.12°.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0095">PXRD and thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The PXRD data reveals that the peak positions of the synthesized crystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> matched with the simulated results from the single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the synthesized samples (). The TGA of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carried out under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere from 35 to 700 °C (). 1 releases three coordinated NMP molecule before 265 °C with a total weight loss of 22.8% (calcd. 23.9%). No further weight loss is observed before the framework collapses at 380 °C. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> loses 9.7% (calcd. 9.8%) weight before 168 °C, corresponding to the departure of one Diox molecule, and the framework could keep intact until about 415 °C, showing good thermal stability. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> loses 11.3% (calcd. 13.3%) weight before 140 °C is assigned to the loss of one free NMP and three coordinated water molecules. The main framework is thermally stable up to 330 °C and then decomposes at a higher temperature. <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> presents a weight loss of 2.1% (calcd. 2.5%) before 190 °C, arising from the release of one coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and one lattice H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0100">Water stability of 1–4</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In order to further study the water stability of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the experiments were carried out by immersing 40 mg of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystals in 5 mL in water at room temperature for some time and the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystalline structures were confirmed by PXRD, respectively. The PXRD patterns contained for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>@H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O are the coincidence of the experimental PXRD patterns with those simulated from the single-crystal structures, respectively, revealing excellent stability in water ().</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0105">Luminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Complexes constructed by d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal centers and conjugated organic linkers are promising candidates in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this paper, the solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligands and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were studied at room temperature. As displayed in , the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L show a strong emission peak at 375 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 330 nm), which may be derived from the intraligand π*-π and/or π*-n transition. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibit a maximum emission peak at 369 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 319 nm), 385 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 330 nm), 453 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 343 nm) and 515 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 356 nm), respectively. The emission spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a slight blue shift of 6 nm at 375 nm compared to that of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L ligand, which can be assigned to the intraligand π-π* or n-π* transition of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L. The emission spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays the slight red shift of 10 nm for the 375 nm band compared to that of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L ligand, which may arise from the ligandcentered π-π* electronic transitions compared to the reported luminescent d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> MOFs . Complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibit an obvious red-shifts of 78 nm and 140 nm for the 375 nm band, respectively, which can be attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of carboxylate groups and p orbitals of Cd(II) and Pb(II) centers, respectively . Moreover, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has an enhanced luminescence intensity compared to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, which can be explained by the differences in the structures. The different emission intensity for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> mainly derives from the differences in the coordination modes of the L<ce:sup loc="post">3-</ce:sup> ligand, and the coordination environments of the metal ions and the rigidity of the solid-state crystal packing. Whereas the rigid and stable framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can reduce this loss of energy and thus maintaining enhanced luminescence intensity. More importantly, it is sensing properties were further researched to detect different metal ions in aqueous solution <ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>

Results and discussion

Crystal structure of {[Zn4(L)2(H2O)4(OH)2]⋅3NMP}n (1)

X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L3-, two coordinated water molecules and one OH- anion. As shown in  a, Zn1 is six connected by two O atoms from two L3- ligands, two water molecules, and two OH- anions, forming a distorted octahedral geometry. Different from that of Zn1, Zn2 is four connected by three carboxylate O atoms from three L3-, and O atom from an OH- anion, showing a distorted tetrahedron coordination geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.952(4) to 2.154(4)Å, and the O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 81.18° to 173.32°.

Crystal structure of {[Zn3(L)3(H2O)2]⋅Diox}n (2)

X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group Pī and contains one and a half crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L3-, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom, which is connected by six O atoms from four L3- ligands and two water molecules, shows a distorted octahedral geometry; while Zn2 atom, which is five connected by four carboxylate O atoms from three L3- and one N atom, shows a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. The Zn-O distances vary from 1.940 (2) to 2.569 (3)Å and the Zn-N distances vary from 2.088 (3)Å. The O-Zn-O angles are in the range from 55.77 (10)° to 180.00 (11)° and the O-Zn-N angles are in the range from 91.22 (9)° to 109.22 (10)°.

In 2, L3- shows one coordination mode (b), and three carboxylate groups reveal three different coordination modes: bridging bidentate (η2μ2χ2), bridging chelating (η2μ1χ2), and monodentate (η1μ2χ2) to coordinate with five Zn(II) ions. In addition, three Zn(II) ions are connected by four bridging carboxylate groups and two monodentate carboxylate groups to form a trinuclear [Zn3(μ1-COO)2 (μ2-COO)4] SBU (b), the SBU is by the Zn1⋯Zn2 separations of 3.2876(4) Å. The SBU is extended by six L3- ligands to produce a 2D layered network viewed along the a direction (b). Finally, the O-H⋯O connected by solvent molecules exist between the neighboring 2D layers, which combine the layers into a 3D supramolecular network (c,  and ). Topologically, the L3- ligand and SBU can be considered as 3, 6-connected nodes, respectively. Thus, 2 discloses a (3,6)-connected  kgd  topology with a point symbol of {43}2{46 66.83} (d).

Crystal structure of {[Cd3(L)2 (H2O)5]⋅NMP⋅3H2O}n (3)

X-ray crystallography shows that complex 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group Pī. The asymmetric unit is made up of three crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions, two fully deprotonated L3- (La and Lb), adopting different coordination models with Cd(II) ions (c), and five coordinated water molecules. As shown in a, Cd1 atom, which is six connected by one N atom from Lb ligand, one water molecule and four O atoms from three Lb ligands, displays a distorted octahedron geometry. Cd2 and Cd3 show a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. Cd2 is seven connected by four O atoms from one La and one Lb ligand, respectively, and three O atoms from three H2O molecules; Cd3 is seven connected by one N atom and five O atoms from three La ligands and one H2O molecule. The Cd-O distances vary from 2.193 (4) to 2.756 (5)Å and the Cd-N distances vary from 2.342 (5) to 2.373 (5)Å. The O-Cd-O angles are in the range from 51.51° to 176.2° and the O-Cd-N angles are in the range from 81.74° to 171.0°.

Crystal structure of {[Pb3(L)2⋅(NMP)2⋅(H2O)]⋅H2O}n (4)

X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group Pī. The asymmetric unit consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Pb(II) ions, one fully deprotonated L3-, one coordinated NMP molecule, and one half coordinated H2O molecule. Structural analysis reveals that there exists 1D infinite rod-shaped metal chain SBUs in the crystal structure (b). As shown in a, there are two types of Pb(II) atoms in the rod SBU. Pb1 is six connected by six O atoms from four L3- ligands, Pb2 is six connected by three O atoms from three L3- ligands, one H2O molecule and two NMP molecules. The Pb-O distances vary from 1.026 (13) to 2.748 (5) Å, and the O-Pb-O angles are in the range from 50.12° to 160.12°.

PXRD and thermal analyses

The PXRD data reveals that the peak positions of the synthesized crystalline samples of 1-4 matched with the simulated results from the single-crystal data, indicating the phase purity of the synthesized samples (). The TGA of 1-4 were carried out under a N2 atmosphere from 35 to 700°C (). 1 releases three coordinated NMP molecule before 265°C with a total weight loss of 22.8% (calcd. 23.9%). No further weight loss is observed before the framework collapses at 380°C. 2 loses 9.7% (calcd. 9.8%) weight before 168°C, corresponding to the departure of one Diox molecule, and the framework could keep intact until about 415°C, showing good thermal stability. 3 loses 11.3% (calcd. 13.3%) weight before 140°C is assigned to the loss of one free NMP and three coordinated water molecules. The main framework is thermally stable up to 330°C and then decomposes at a higher temperature. 4 presents a weight loss of 2.1% (calcd. 2.5%) before 190°C, arising from the release of one coordinated H2O and one lattice H2O molecules.

Water stability of 1-4

In order to further study the water stability of the 1-4, the experiments were carried out by immersing 40mg of 1-4 crystals in 5mL in water at room temperature for some time and the 1-4 crystalline structures were confirmed by PXRD, respectively. The PXRD patterns contained for 1-4@H2O are the coincidence of the experimental PXRD patterns with those simulated from the single-crystal structures, respectively, revealing excellent stability in water ().

Luminescence properties

Complexes constructed by d10 metal centers and conjugated organic linkers are promising candidates in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this paper, the solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligands and 1-4 were studied at room temperature. As displayed in , the free H3L show a strong emission peak at 375nm (λex =330nm), which may be derived from the intraligand π*-π and/or π*-n transition. Complexes 1-4 exhibit a maximum emission peak at 369nm (λex =319nm), 385nm (λex =330nm), 453nm (λex =343nm) and 515nm (λex =356nm), respectively. The emission spectrum of 1 exhibits a slight blue shift of 6nm at 375nm compared to that of H3L ligand, which can be assigned to the intraligand π-π* or n-π* transition of H3L. The emission spectrum of 2 displays the slight red shift of 10nm for the 375nm band compared to that of H3L ligand, which may arise from the ligandcentered π-π* electronic transitions compared to the reported luminescent d10 MOFs . Complexes 3-4 exhibit an obvious red-shifts of 78nm and 140nm for the 375nm band, respectively, which can be attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) between the delocalized π-bond of carboxylate groups and p orbitals of Cd(II) and Pb(II) centers, respectively . Moreover, complex 1 has an enhanced luminescence intensity compared to 2-4, which can be explained by the differences in the structures. The different emission intensity for 1-4 mainly derives from the differences in the coordination modes of the L3- ligand, and the coordination environments of the metal ions and the rigidity of the solid-state crystal packing. Whereas the rigid and stable framework of 1 can reduce this loss of energy and thus maintaining enhanced luminescence intensity. More importantly, it is sensing properties were further researched to detect different metal ions in aqueous solution  .

To assess the sensitivity of 1 toward Fe3+ in detail, varying concentrations of Fe3+ were introduced into suspension of 1. The results from a titration experiment (c) shown that the luminescence intensity of 1 clearly decrease gradually with increasing. The Stern-Volmer equation was used to calculate the corresponding quenching coefficients, showing it to be a diffusion-controlled quenching process . The relationship between the relative luminescence intensity and the concentration of Fe3+ ions can be fitted well with the Stern-Volmer formula: I0/I=6×103 [M]+0.86 (R2 =0.995), showing that luminescence quenching is diffusion-controlled (I0 =the luminescence intensity of the 1@H2O suspension; I = the luminescence intensity of the 1@Fe3+ suspensions, [M] = the Fe3+ concentration (mM)) (d). When the concentration of Fe3+ ions reached 0.99mM, the luminescence intensity of 1 is quenched with quenching efficiency of 86% (quenching percentage = (I0-I)/I0 ×100%). For Fe3+, the SV plots are nearly linear in the low concentration range and the Ksv value is calculated to about 6×103 M-1 (d), the calculated detection limit of complex 1 for Fe3+ ions can reach as low as 1.25×10-5 M according to 3δ/Ksv, where δ is standard error and K is slope. The high KSV value and low detection limit, which is compared to previously reported compounds for sensing Fe3+ []. The lower detection limit suggests that complex 1 exhibits high detection sensitivity toward Fe3+.

To further prove that the fluorescence quenching by the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-, concentration-dependent studies in the luminescence properties of 1. As shown in (c, f), the luminescence intensity of the 1 suspension declines sharply with the increase of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- concentration from 0 to 1×10-3 M. When the concentration of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- were increased to 1.29 and 1.47mM, the luminescence was completely quenched with a high quenching efficiency of 93% and 98%, respectively. The relationship between I0/I and the concentration of CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions didn't fit the Stern-Volmer equation, indicating the coexistence of a dynamic and static quenching process, which can be well fitted as the following formula: I0/I =4.492exp([M]/ 0.683) - 4.007 and I0/I=0.714exp([M]/0.347)+0.195, respectively (I0 and I are the luminescence intensity of the 1@H2O and 1@anion suspensions, respectively; [M] is the concentration (mM) of the anion). For the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions, the plot of I0/I vs. [M] can be well fitted by the Stern-Volmer equation I0/I=1+Ksv[M] and the SV plots are nearly linear in the low concentration range (d, f, insets). The Ksv values were calculated to about 1.2×104 M-1 and 5.78×103 M-1, respectively. According to the Ksv values and the standard deviations for repeated luminescence measurements of blank solutions, the detection limits (3δ/ksv) of complex 1 was also calculated. For complex 1, the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2- anions are the most obviously quenchers with detection limits of 2.2×10-6 M, 1.7×10-5 M, which are compared to the reported values of some other compounds in the literature []. The low detection limits indicate that complex 1 exhibits extremely high detection sensitivity toward the CrO4 2- and Cr2O7 2-.
